and the Buddhist band EP but here's

know how this is going to go the
Afrobeat insall sounds that made the
Buddha span such a force to be reckoned
with inside of instrumental music are
still in full force on this new album so
there's really no reason to worry there
this album features a lot of heavy horns
some decent grooves and a plethora of
percussion but you know almost every
track just has something on it that
maybe feels a bit off it is a real
change in mood for the Bhutto's band way
moodier a lot darker using a lot of
minor scale melodies a lot of dissonant
chords it's really just not a sound that
I'm vibing with and the organ which I
know has always played a vital role in
the Buddhist music has this tone on it
this effect just this sound it's like
something out of an old silent horror
film oh it's kind of creepy but also
kind of kitschy it's a sound that the
vamp just refuses to distance themselves
from on any track of this album every
time the organ shows up it sounds like
that so not only is the slightly darker
mood not doing much of anything for me
but there's also a lot of recycling on
this album and I mean a lot of recycling
tons of songs just start off the exact
same way many of the openings just being
based on maybe a dark guitar chord or a
tinny
our riff just these really repetitive
guitar phrases that are giving me deja
vu and in contrast especially on the
Buddhist band album Buddhist band two
maybe two tracks on that LP start the
same there's a ton of variation
throughout those songs whether it be in
terms of instrumentation or just the
style the band is shooting for on that
given track but it's not like this LP
doesn't have its breaths of fresh air
the track crimson skies has really even
mixed with a lot of atmosphere and space
between the instruments it's really easy
to pull apart and just kind of enjoy the
sound that each instrument is creating
as opposed to a lot of tracks on this LP
where the horns are just really
overbearing and just blaring over
everything just drowning out a lot of
vital instrumentation and I've dug the
fifth track nature's wrath a lot mostly
because it was just a nice change of
speed from the mid-tempo that much of
this album seems to just be locked in
and refusing to move away from this
track was one of the darkest on the
album and really where that emotion kind
of hit home for me and just worked I
don't know but a major gripe a major
gripe about this track is that the
guitar melody sounds shockingly similar
to a track off of the Buddhist band's
second album origin of man what the
Buddhist band does is really defined and
this LP is an example of how that can be
a double-edged sword it can be great
because when you hear a band with a very
distinct and defined sound oh you know
who it is right off the bat it feels
familiar you're pretty much going to go
to them to get that sound however you
kind of look for them at the next go
around to kind of change things up do
things a little bit differently and not
repeat themselves over and over and yet
still maintain that familiarity I could
see where they're trying to distance
themselves from their previous efforts
by sounding a little bit darker but only
through doing that they've kind of ended
up just repeating themselves on their
earlier work a couple times and
repeating themselves on this new album a

say what
thinking I have to say what I'm actually

okay but it's really not at the same
